title: Isaiah Chapter 14 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Isaiah chapter 14 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Isaiah Chapter 14 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Isaiah Chapter 14.

questions.question: Who will the LORD have mercy on according to Isaiah 14:1?
questions.correctAnswer: Jacob
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:1 states that the LORD will have mercy on Jacob and choose Israel.

questions.question: In Isaiah 14:4, the proverb is taken up against which king?
questions.correctAnswer: King of Babylon
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:4 mentions taking up a proverb against the king of Babylon.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 14:7, what is the condition of the whole earth?
questions.correctAnswer: At rest and quiet
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:7 states the whole earth is at rest and quiet, and people break forth into singing.

questions.question: Who is said to rejoice in Isaiah 14:8 because no feller has come against them?
options: Fir trees and cedars of Lebanon
questions.correctAnswer: Fir trees and cedars of Lebanon
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:8 mentions the fir trees and cedars of Lebanon rejoicing because no feller has come up against them.

questions.question: In Isaiah 14:12, who is described as fallen from heaven?
questions.correctAnswer: Lucifer, son of the morning
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:12 describes Lucifer, son of the morning, as fallen from heaven.

questions.question: What does Lucifer say in his heart according to Isaiah 14:13?
questions.correctAnswer: I will ascend into heaven
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:13 records Lucifer saying in his heart he will ascend into heaven and exalt his throne.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 14:15, where shall Lucifer be brought down?
options: To hell, to the sides of the pit
questions.correctAnswer: To hell, to the sides of the pit
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:15 states Lucifer shall be brought down to hell, to the sides of the pit.

questions.question: What do those who see Lucifer say in Isaiah 14:16?
options: Is this the man that made the earth to tremble?
Is this the king of Babylon?
Is this the servant of God?
Is this the ruler of Israel?
questions.correctAnswer: Is this the man that made the earth to tremble?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:16 records people questioning if this is the man that made the earth tremble.

questions.question: What is said about the burial of Lucifer in Isaiah 14:20?
options: He shall not be joined with them in burial
He shall be buried with kings
He shall be buried in the holy land
questions.correctAnswer: He shall not be joined with them in burial
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:20 explains Lucifer shall not be joined with others in burial due to his destruction of the land and people.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 14:5 says the LORD has strengthened the staff of the wicked.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:5 states the LORD hath broken the staff of the wicked, not strengthened it.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 14:25 promises the LORD will break the Assyrian in His land.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:25 affirms that the LORD will break the Assyrian in His land and tread him under foot.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 14:29 says to rejoice because the rod of him that smote thee is broken.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:29 instructs not to rejoice because the rod of him that smote thee is broken.

questions.question: Complete the verse from Isaiah 14:3: 'And it shall come to pass in the day that the LORD shall give thee rest from thy _______, and from thy fear.'
questions.correctAnswer: sorrow
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:3 mentions the LORD giving rest from sorrow and fear.

questions.question: Complete the phrase from Isaiah 14:22: 'For I will rise up against them, saith the LORD of hosts, and cut off from Babylon the _______, and remnant, and son, and nephew.'
questions.correctAnswer: name
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:22 states the LORD will cut off from Babylon the name and remnant and son and nephew.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 14:31, what will come from the north?
questions.correctAnswer: Smoke
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:31 says smoke will come from the north, causing dissolution in Palestina.

medium.title: Isaiah Chapter 14 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Isaiah Chapter 14 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Isaiah 14, what biblical truth would you share about God's faithfulness and mercy?
options: The LORD will have mercy and restore His people to their land
God will abandon His people during hardships
Human strength is the only source of relief
Oppressors will always remain in power
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD will have mercy and restore His people to their land
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:1-3 teaches that God will have mercy on Jacob, choose Israel again, and give rest from sorrow and bondage, showing His faithfulness and care toward His people.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 14 illustrate the importance of trusting God's sovereignty in times of oppression?
options: God breaks the staff of the wicked and the scepter of rulers
Human rulers must be overthrown by force
Trusting human leaders is sufficient for peace
questions.correctAnswer: God breaks the staff of the wicked and the scepter of rulers
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:4-6 shows that God actively breaks the power of oppressors, encouraging believers to trust His sovereign control rather than human strength alone.

questions.question: A believer struggling with fear is encouraged by Isaiah 14. What does the chapter reveal about God's ability to bring peace amid turmoil?
options: The whole earth is at rest and breaks into singing
Fear will always dominate the earth
Peace depends on human effort only
questions.correctAnswer: The whole earth is at rest and breaks into singing
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:7-8 describes the earth resting and rejoicing, symbolizing God's power to bring peace and calm, which encourages believers to place their trust in Him.

questions.question: What warning about pride and self-exaltation can be drawn from Isaiah 14's depiction of Lucifer's fall?
options: Pride leads to downfall and destruction
questions.correctAnswer: Pride leads to downfall and destruction
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:12-15 shows Lucifer's pride in wanting to be like the Most High led to his fall, teaching believers humility and caution against prideful ambition.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 14 teach us about humility and contentment through the fate of the oppressor?
options: The oppressor is brought down to the grave and forgotten
Contentment comes from wealth and power
questions.correctAnswer: The oppressor is brought down to the grave and forgotten
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:16-20 describes how the mighty oppressor is cast out and not honored in burial, emphasizing the value of humility and the fleeting nature of earthly power.

questions.question: A believer faces temptation to seek revenge against oppressors. What biblical truth from Isaiah 14 would help them respond rightly?
options: God will rule over oppressors and bring justice
Taking revenge is the believer's duty
questions.correctAnswer: God will rule over oppressors and bring justice
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:2 and 22-23 reveal that God will bring judgment and rule over oppressors, encouraging believers to trust God’s justice rather than taking matters into their own hands.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 14 teach about perseverance through trials and God's ultimate purpose?
options: God's purpose will stand and no one can annul it
Trials are meaningless and without purpose
questions.correctAnswer: God's purpose will stand and no one can annul it
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:24-27 emphasizes that God's plans are certain and unstoppable, encouraging believers to persevere in faith during difficult times.

questions.question: Based on Isaiah 14, how should believers view the consequences of sin and evil deeds within families?
options: The iniquity of fathers can affect their children
Children are always free from consequences
Evil deeds bring only personal consequences
questions.correctAnswer: The iniquity of fathers can affect their children
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:21 speaks of preparing slaughter for children for the iniquity of their fathers, warning believers about the lasting impact of sin but also encouraging repentance and correction.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 14 teaches that God will allow the oppressor to remain indefinitely without consequence.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:5-6 and 22-23 show that God breaks the power of oppressors and will cut off Babylon’s name and remnant, demonstrating that oppressors will face consequences.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 14 encourages believers to rejoice because God has founded Zion and the poor shall trust in it.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:32 affirms that the LORD has founded Zion and the poor of His people shall trust in it, giving cause for rejoicing and confidence in God's care.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to Isaiah 14, the LORD hath sworn that He will break the _____ in His land and tread him under foot.
questions.correctAnswer: Assyrian
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:25 declares that the LORD will break the Assyrian in His land and tread him under foot, illustrating God's power to defeat enemies and bring deliverance.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 14 teach believers about contentment and humility in leadership and power?
options: Prideful leaders are ultimately humbled and destroyed
Leaders should seek to exalt themselves above God
Power and arrogance guarantee lasting success
Human authority is supreme and unchallengeable
questions.correctAnswer: Prideful leaders are ultimately humbled and destroyed
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:12-20 describes the fall of Lucifer and the downfall of mighty kings, teaching the dangers of pride and the importance of humility before God.

questions.question: A believer is discouraged by the evil in the world. According to Isaiah 14, what hope can you share about God's justice and restoration?
options: God will bring an end to oppression and restore His people
questions.correctAnswer: God will bring an end to oppression and restore His people
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:1-3 and 22-23 show God's promise to have mercy on Israel, set them in their land, and destroy Babylon's power, assuring believers of His ultimate justice and restoration.

questions.question: What practical lesson about prayer and trusting God can be drawn from Isaiah 14's depiction of God's control over nations?
options: God's hand is stretched out over all nations and His purpose cannot be turned back
Prayer has no effect on worldly events
Nations act independently of God's will
Believers should rely only on political power
questions.correctAnswer: God's hand is stretched out over all nations and His purpose cannot be turned back
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:26-27 emphasizes that God's purpose is fixed and His hand is stretched out over all nations, encouraging believers to pray and trust God's sovereign plan.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 14 teach about the importance of spiritual vigilance against temptation?
options: The root of evil will produce destructive offspring, like a fiery flying serpent
Temptation is harmless and need not be guarded against
Evil cannot reproduce or affect others
One can ignore spiritual dangers safely
questions.correctAnswer: The root of evil will produce destructive offspring, like a fiery flying serpent
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:29 warns that out of the serpent's root will come a cockatrice and fiery flying serpent, symbolizing ongoing spiritual danger requiring vigilance and prayer.

hard.title: Isaiah Chapter 14 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Isaiah Chapter 14.

questions.question: In Isaiah 14:12, the figure called 'Lucifer, son of the morning' is traditionally understood as a symbol for which entity?
questions.correctAnswer: The king of Babylon
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:12 uses 'Lucifer, son of the morning' as a poetic and symbolic reference to the king of Babylon, illustrating his fall from power.

questions.question: Which literary device is prominently used in Isaiah 14:4 where a proverb is taken up against the king of Babylon?
questions.correctAnswer: Proverbial parallelism
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:4 introduces a proverb, a form of parallelism common in Hebrew poetry, contrasting the oppressor's previous power with his cessation.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 14:3, what will the LORD give to the people to relieve them?
options: Rest from sorrow, fear, and hard bondage
questions.correctAnswer: Rest from sorrow, fear, and hard bondage
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:3 promises that the LORD will grant rest from sorrow, fear, and the hard bondage that the people endured, signifying deliverance.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 14:11 metaphorically describe as covering the fallen one?
questions.correctAnswer: Worms
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:11 uses the imagery of worms covering the fallen one to emphasize decay and mortality after the fall.

questions.question: Isaiah 14:13-14 describes the prideful intentions of the fallen king. What was his ambition?
options: To ascend above the clouds and be like the Most High
To amass great wealth and treasures
To build a tower reaching heaven
questions.correctAnswer: To ascend above the clouds and be like the Most High
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:13-14 illustrates the king's ambition to exalt himself above God by ascending into heaven and claiming divine status.

questions.question: In Isaiah 14:15, where is the fallen king said to be brought down to?
options: Hell, to the sides of the pit
questions.correctAnswer: Hell, to the sides of the pit
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:15 states the fallen king will be brought down to hell, symbolizing complete humiliation and defeat.

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'rod' mentioned in Isaiah 14:29 in the context of ancient Near Eastern symbolism?
options: It symbolizes the power of oppression and judgment
It is a sign of divine blessing
It represents the scepter of David
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes the power of oppression and judgment
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:29's reference to the 'rod' symbolizes the instrument of oppression and punishment, common in ancient Near Eastern royal imagery.

questions.question: Which theme in Isaiah 14 reflects a broader biblical motif of divine justice against oppressive empires?
options: The fall of Babylon as an oppressor
The establishment of the Davidic dynasty
questions.correctAnswer: The fall of Babylon as an oppressor
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14 centers on the downfall of Babylon, echoing the biblical theme of God executing justice against oppressive empires.

questions.question: How does the depiction of the fallen king in Isaiah 14:9-10 connect with ancient Near Eastern beliefs about the afterlife?
options: The dead and kings from their thrones rise to meet him, indicating the realm of the dead
He becomes a god in the underworld
He is immediately resurrected to heaven
He is forgotten and erased from memory
questions.correctAnswer: The dead and kings from their thrones rise to meet him, indicating the realm of the dead
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:9-10 depicts the underworld stirring and kings rising from their thrones, reflecting ancient Near Eastern ideas of the dead in Sheol.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 14:27 emphasizes the invincibility of God's purposes against all nations.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:27 states that God's hand is stretched out and no one can turn it back, affirming the certainty of His purposes.

questions.question: What is the 'besom of destruction' mentioned in Isaiah 14:23 a metaphor for?
questions.correctAnswer: God's sweeping judgment upon Babylon
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:23 uses 'besom of destruction' metaphorically to describe God's thorough and sweeping judgment against Babylon.

questions.question: How is the theme of restoration portrayed in Isaiah 14:1-2?
options: The LORD will have mercy on Jacob and set Israel in their own land with strangers joining them
The Assyrian king will be restored to power
Babylon will be rebuilt as a glorious city
The nations will be destroyed without restoration
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD will have mercy on Jacob and set Israel in their own land with strangers joining them
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:1-2 expresses restoration where God shows mercy to Israel, resettling them in their land and incorporating strangers.

questions.question: What historical context does Isaiah 14:25 provide regarding the Assyrian empire?
options: God will break the Assyrian yoke and tread them underfoot in His land
Assyria will become an ally of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: God will break the Assyrian yoke and tread them underfoot in His land
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:25 proclaims God's promise to break Assyrian oppression and remove their burden from His people, reflecting historical Assyrian threats.

questions.question: In Isaiah 14:21, what is the purpose of preparing slaughter for the children of the fallen king?
options: To prevent them from rising and possessing the land or filling the world with cities
To make them kings of other nations
To convert them to worship Israel’s God
To exile them to a distant land
questions.correctAnswer: To prevent them from rising and possessing the land or filling the world with cities
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:21 explains slaughter is prepared to stop the descendants from reclaiming land or expanding cities, reflecting divine judgment on generational iniquity.

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'cockatrice' and 'fiery flying serpent' imagery in Isaiah 14:29?
options: They symbolize a new, more dangerous threat rising from the serpent’s root
They represent the peace and prosperity of Palestine
They are blessings promised to Israel
They are literal animals invading the land
questions.correctAnswer: They symbolize a new, more dangerous threat rising from the serpent’s root
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:29 uses these serpent images metaphorically to illustrate a dangerous and fiery threat arising after the fall of the former oppressor.

theological.title: Isaiah Chapter 14 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Isaiah Chapter 14 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 14, what will the LORD do for Jacob and Israel?
options: Have mercy on Jacob and set Israel in their own land
Destroy Jacob and scatter Israel among the nations
Ignore Israel and leave them in exile
Make Jacob a servant to foreign kings
questions.correctAnswer: Have mercy on Jacob and set Israel in their own land
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:1 states that the LORD will have mercy on Jacob and choose Israel to be set in their own land. This reflects God's promises of restoration seen in Jeremiah 30:3, Ezekiel 37:21-22, Romans 11:26, and Revelation 7:4-8.

questions.question: What is the significance of the proverb against the king of Babylon in Isaiah 14?
options: It illustrates the fall of a proud oppressor
It predicts Babylon's alliance with Israel
It encourages rebellion against the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: It illustrates the fall of a proud oppressor
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:4 introduces a proverb against the king of Babylon highlighting the downfall of a proud oppressor. This theme is echoed in Luke 1:51-53, Psalm 2:4-9, Daniel 4:17, and Revelation 18:10 which all focus on God's judgment on oppressive rulers.

questions.question: What does the LORD do to the staff and sceptre of the wicked rulers according to Isaiah 14?
questions.correctAnswer: Breaks them
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:5 declares that the LORD breaks the staff of the wicked and the sceptre of rulers, symbolizing the removal of their oppressive power. This is consistent with passages like Psalm 2:9, Daniel 2:44, Luke 1:52, and Revelation 19:15 where God's sovereignty over earthly powers is affirmed.

questions.question: How does Isaiah describe the earth's reaction to the fall of the oppressor?
options: The earth is at rest and breaks forth into singing
The earth trembles and shakes with fear
The earth remains silent and dark
The earth rebels against the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: The earth is at rest and breaks forth into singing
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:7 says the whole earth is at rest and breaks forth into singing at the fall of the oppressor. This joy in God's deliverance is also found in Psalm 98:4-9, Revelation 5:13, Isaiah 44:23, and Romans 8:21-22.

questions.question: Who are stirred up from the dead to meet the king of Babylon upon his coming as described in Isaiah 14?
options: All the chief ones of the earth including kings
questions.correctAnswer: All the chief ones of the earth including kings
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:9 reveals that hell stirs up the dead, including all the chief ones and kings of the earth, to meet the fallen king of Babylon. This imagery of the dead rising before judgment is echoed in Ezekiel 32:21, Daniel 12:2, John 5:28-29, and Revelation 20:13.

questions.question: What title is given to the fallen figure in Isaiah 14:12, and what is his fate?
options: Lucifer, son of the morning, fallen from heaven
Michael, the archangel, victorious in battle
Elijah, the prophet, taken to heaven
questions.correctAnswer: Lucifer, son of the morning, fallen from heaven
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:12 calls the fallen figure 'Lucifer, son of the morning,' describing his fall from heaven. This passage is traditionally understood as a poetic reference to the pride and fall of a powerful being. Related scriptures include Ezekiel 28:12-19, Luke 10:18, Revelation 12:7-9, and 2 Peter 2:4, all describing rebellion and downfall of proud spiritual beings.

questions.question: What ambition did the fallen figure express in his heart according to Isaiah 14?
options: To ascend into heaven and be like the Most High
To build a temple for God
questions.correctAnswer: To ascend into heaven and be like the Most High
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:13-14 records the prideful ambition of ascending to heaven and exalting the throne above the stars of God to be like the Most High. This reflects the sin of pride and rebellion against God's sovereignty, paralleled in Proverbs 16:18, Ezekiel 28:17, James 4:6, and 1 Timothy 3:6.

questions.question: What ultimate judgment is pronounced on the proud figure in Isaiah 14?
options: He will be brought down to hell, to the sides of the pit
He will be forgiven and restored
He will become a servant to Israel
questions.correctAnswer: He will be brought down to hell, to the sides of the pit
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:15 declares that the proud one will be brought down to hell (Sheol), indicating eternal judgment. This fate is consistent with other scriptures such as Matthew 25:41, Jude 1:6, Revelation 20:10, and 2 Thessalonians 1:9, which depict the final judgment of the wicked.

questions.question: How do observers react when they see the fallen oppressor according to Isaiah 14?
options: They question if this is the man who made the earth tremble
They worship him as a god
questions.correctAnswer: They question if this is the man who made the earth tremble
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:16 describes people narrowly looking upon the fallen oppressor and questioning, 'Is this the man that made the earth to tremble?' This reflects the reversal of fortunes seen in Job 12:23, Psalm 37:10-12, Daniel 4:35, and Luke 1:52 where God humbles the proud and exalts the humble.

questions.question: Why will the fallen king not be joined with the kings in burial according to Isaiah 14?
options: Because he destroyed his land and slew his people
Because he was a righteous king
Because he was honored by all nations
Because he repented and turned to God
questions.correctAnswer: Because he destroyed his land and slew his people
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:20 explains that the fallen king will not be buried with other kings because he destroyed his land and people. This judgment against tyrants is echoed in Ezekiel 32:27, Jeremiah 22:18-19, Proverbs 28:5, and Revelation 6:10.

questions.question: What does the LORD say He will do to Babylon according to Isaiah 14?
options: Cut off its name, remnant, son, and nephew
Make it the capital of the world
Raise it up as a holy city
questions.correctAnswer: Cut off its name, remnant, son, and nephew
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:22 states the LORD will rise against Babylon and cut off its name and remnant. This signifies total judgment and removal, consistent with Jeremiah 51:26, Daniel 5:30, Revelation 18:21, and Zephaniah 2:13-15 which all prophesy Babylon's destruction.

questions.question: What is the meaning of the LORD’s 'besom of destruction' mentioned in Isaiah 14?
options: A broom sweeping away Babylon as a possession for creatures
A sword to conquer Israel’s enemies
A shield to protect His people
A crown to exalt the righteous
questions.correctAnswer: A broom sweeping away Babylon as a possession for creatures
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:23 uses the metaphor of the LORD sweeping Babylon with a besom (broom) of destruction, symbolizing complete cleansing and desolation. This aligns with imagery in Jeremiah 51:33, Ezekiel 38:23, Zechariah 13:8, and Revelation 18:2 about God's decisive judgment.

questions.question: What does Isaiah declare about the LORD’s purpose and its certainty in Isaiah 14?
options: The LORD’s purpose shall come to pass and no one can disannul it
The LORD’s purpose is uncertain and may be changed
The LORD depends on human approval to act
The LORD’s plans are secret and unknown
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD’s purpose shall come to pass and no one can disannul it
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:24-27 affirm the certainty and invincibility of God's purpose and hand stretched out over all nations, echoing God's sovereign will in Psalm 33:11, Proverbs 19:21, Romans 8:28-30, and Ephesians 1:11.

questions.question: What warning is given to Palestina in Isaiah 14 after the death of King Ahaz?
options: Do not rejoice because a new serpent will arise
Ignore the troubles coming from the north
questions.correctAnswer: Do not rejoice because a new serpent will arise
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:29 warns Palestina not to rejoice because out of the serpent’s root will come a cockatrice and fiery flying serpent, symbolizing renewed danger. This is supported by Genesis 3:15, Psalm 58:4-6, Proverbs 23:32, and Revelation 12:9 about ongoing spiritual opposition.

questions.question: What promise is given to the poor and needy in Isaiah 14?
options: They shall feed and lie down in safety
They shall be ignored by God
questions.correctAnswer: They shall feed and lie down in safety
questions.explanation: Isaiah 14:30 promises that the firstborn of the poor shall feed and the needy shall lie down in safety, reflecting God's care for the vulnerable as seen in Psalm 9:18, Matthew 5:3-6, Luke 1:52, and James 2:5.
